title: Themes and Topics
text:
Strategic Spatial Frameworks – comprehensive plans guiding urban or regional development strategies.
Integrated Climate Adaptation Plans – proposals combining design, policy, and resilience measures for climate adaptation.
Scenario-Based Design Studies – exploring alternative future scenarios to inform design decisions.
Cross-Case Comparative Analyses – comparative studies across multiple urban contexts or projects to derive transferable insights.
Data-Driven Design Prototypes – design proposals emphasizing performance metrics, simulation, and visual analytics to support decision-making.

title: Themes and Topics
text:

title: DATA-INFORMED STRATEGIES FOR SUSTAINABLE URBAN FUTURES
text:
Welcome to a graduation cluster where your designs meet data and your ideas tackle real urban challenges.
In this cluster, you will learn to use spatial data, modeling, and analytics to create sustainable, climate-resilient cities—designing solutions that respond to growing pressure from urbanization, flooding, heat stress, and resource scarcity. From neighborhoods to regions, you will explore how data can guide innovative, context-sensitive spatial strategies.
You’ll dive into mapping climate vulnerability, planning adaptations across jurisdictions, and integrating environmental, infrastructural, and social data into actionable frameworks. You will work with GIS, scenario modeling, multicriteria analysis, simulations, and machine learning, turning complex datasets into clear, evidence-based design insights.
Data here is a tool, not the goal. You will translate analytics into visionary, grounded design proposals that are both practical and imaginative. Along the way, you will build technical skills, sharpen strategic thinking, and learn to communicate and collaborate effectively across disciplines—preparing you for professional work in design, planning, policy, or consultancy.
By the end of the graduation, you won’t just have designs, you’ll have tested strategies, transferable knowledge, and the confidence to contribute to sustainable, climate-ready urban futures.

title: DATA-INFORMED STRATEGIES FOR SUSTAINABLE URBAN FUTURES
About
text:
This cluster explores how data-informed approaches can support the design of climate-resilient urban environments. As cities increasingly face pressures such as flooding, heat stress, and resource scarcity, urbanism should harness the growing availability of urban data, analytics, and digital tools to evolve toward integrated, evidence-based, and context-sensitive design practices. The cluster investigates how spatial data, modeling, and analysis can support innovative strategies operating across scales – from neighbourhoods to regions - and respond to specific urban challenges.
The scope of the cluster includes pressing spatial and policy issues such as climate vulnerability mapping, adaptation planning across jurisdictions, and integrating diverse data types (e.g., environmental, infrastructural, social) into actionable frameworks. Methodologically, the cluster bridges the gap between advanced spatial analytics and projective design by embedding large and diverse spatial-temporal datasets and leveraging analytical workflows and machine learning methods (such as S-MCDA, simulations, predictive models, and clustering) into the design process. The focus is on quantitative and mixed-methods approaches, aligned with Open Science principles such as reproducibility and FAIR data. Students are encouraged to share and publish their data and workflows alongside their design outputs.
Students will engage with both analytical tools and exploratory, strategic design. The process will begin with data exploration - using GIS, scenario modeling, and multicriteria analysis - and progress toward spatial design interventions. The emphasis is on design-research: data is used not as an end but as a foundation for vision-driven, grounded design proposals.
Students will develop a robust skill set, including technical competencies, strategic thinking, and the ability to synthesize insights across disciplines. They will strengthen their ability to communicate data-supported ideas clearly and collaborate in interdisciplinary teams - skills essential for future professionals in design, planning, policy, or consultancy.
By working across cases and scales, students will explore how climate adaptation strategies can be localized, compared, and transferred. By the end of the studio, they will be equipped to contribute to sustainable urban futures with creativity, confidence, and analytical rigour.

title: Contact us
text: Have questions about our research or interested in collaboration? We’d love to hear from you.

title: Graduation Project Highlights
text:
Graduation Project Highlights
Curious what graduation work looks like in this cluster?
Here are some examples from previous students. Each project shows a different way of combining spatial data, analysis, and design to respond to real urban challenges. Use these projects as inspiration when developing your own ideas.


Clean Corridors
M. van der Waal, 2024
A data-driven design for multi-scale green infrastructure design.


Landscape-Based Fire Resilience
J. Song, 2023
Identifying interaction between landscape dynamics and fire regimes in the Mediterranean region.


Bridging Past and Future
L.A. van Lun, 2024
Utilising cultural heritage values to increase resilience in Amsterdam’s polder water system.






 Back to top
